definitely_too_advanced.title: Analyze unintended systemic impacts of a technology
definitely_too_advanced.short_name: How does one technology change everything?
definitely_too_advanced.description: Students examine how a single technology can create ripple effects across society (e.g., smartphones enabling communication but also job displacement in certain sectors, social media enabling connection but also affecting mental health). They map systems and second-order effects.

definitely_too_advanced.title: Reflect on accuracy, bias, and quality of generated code
definitely_too_advanced.short_name: Evaluate code for correctness and bias
definitely_too_advanced.description: Students review code (either their own or AI-generated) and consider questions like: Does it correctly solve the stated problem? Are there edge cases it misses? Could it introduce bias or unintended harm? What assumptions does it make? This critical analysis develops higher-order thinking about code quality.

definitely_too_advanced.title: Analyze two variables for potential causal relationships
definitely_too_advanced.short_name: Explore whether one variable affects another
definitely_too_advanced.description: Students investigate whether a relationship between two variables suggests causation (e.g., does study time cause higher test scores?) or is merely correlation. They consider alternative explanations and limitations of the data.

borderline.title: Understand why different algorithms are chosen for different problems
borderline.short_name: Choose the right algorithm for the task
borderline.description: Given a problem, students consider multiple possible algorithms and justify which is most appropriate based on efficiency, clarity, or fit. Example: Why use a specific sorting algorithm over repeated swaps? Why use binary search instead of linear? This develops algorithmic decision-making.

borderline.title: Represent an algorithm in pseudocode or text code
borderline.short_name: Write pseudocode for an algorithm
borderline.description: Students transition from block-based code to pseudocode or simple text-based code representation. They write an algorithm in plain language with code-like structure (e.g., "for each item in list: if item > max, set max = item"). This bridges to more formal programming.

borderline.title: Analyze an algorithm for correctness on edge cases
borderline.short_name: Test an algorithm on tricky inputs
borderline.description: Students test an algorithm (given in code or pseudocode) on edge cases (empty input, single item, maximum/minimum values, repeats) and identify if it fails and why. This develops rigorous thinking about algorithm robustness.

borderline.title: Design a flowchart for a sorting or search algorithm
borderline.short_name: Create a flowchart for finding or organizing data
borderline.description: Students create a flowchart for a simple algorithmic task such as linear search, bubble sort, or selection sort, using appropriate decision points and loops to represent the logic.

borderline.title: Analyze algorithm complexity and steps required
borderline.short_name: Count steps in algorithms and compare efficiency
borderline.description: Students analyze two algorithms that solve the same problem and count or estimate the number of steps (or time complexity in intuitive terms) each requires for different input sizes, reasoning about which is more efficient.

borderline.title: Trace an algorithm and identify a bug or edge case
borderline.short_name: Find where an algorithm fails
borderline.description: Students trace an algorithm (in pseudocode or code) with specific inputs, identify a case where it produces an incorrect result, and explain why (e.g., "When the list is empty, it crashes" or "When the target is at the end, it takes too long").

borderline.title: Use custom blocks to implement algorithms
borderline.short_name: Code an algorithm as a custom block
borderline.description: Students implement standard or simple algorithms (e.g., linear search, bubble sort, greatest common divisor) as custom blocks with clear parameters and return values, demonstrating that a complex algorithm can be encapsulated in a reusable block.

borderline.title: Examine bias in AI-generated images and discuss causes
borderline.short_name: Recognize and discuss bias in AI art
borderline.description: Students systematically test AI image generators with prompts that should yield diverse results (e.g., "a doctor," "a teacher," "a CEO"). They observe whether the AI perpetuates stereotypes based on gender, race, age, or other factors, and discuss why training data bias causes this.

borderline.title: Critique XO's suggestions against your priorities
borderline.short_name: Evaluate whether XO's idea fits your project
borderline.description: XO might suggest a sophisticated optimization or feature that's technically sound but doesn't align with a student's project goals (e.g., XO suggests a complex sorting algorithm when the student's list is tiny, or XO suggests a 3D feature when the project is 2D). Students learn to say "That's smart, but not what I need for this project" and explain why.

borderline.title: Compare distributions of data
borderline.short_name: Compare shape and spread of two datasets
borderline.description: Students compare two datasets (e.g., two classes' test scores, rainfall in two cities) by looking at their distributions: shape (skew, symmetry), center (mean or median), and spread (range, variability). They describe which dataset is more consistent or has more extreme values.

borderline.title: Implement a Monte Carlo simulation to estimate a probability
borderline.short_name: Run 1000s of trials to estimate odds
borderline.description: Students code a simulation using a large number of iterations (e.g., 1000 or 10,000 trials) to empirically estimate a complex probability (e.g., chance of rolling three dice that sum to 10, or chance of at least two people sharing a birthday in a room of 20). They interpret the frequency as a probability estimate.

borderline.title: Evaluate algorithmic bias in AI services
borderline.short_name: Recognize bias in AI tools
borderline.description: Students learn that AI services (like ChatGPT, translation, or image generation) can have biases. For example, ChatGPT might give different answers based on how a question is phrased, or an image generator might produce stereotyped results. Students think about impacts and responsibility.

borderline.title: Understand recursion conceptually (algorithm calling itself)
borderline.short_name: Recognize recursive structure in problems
borderline.description: Students encounter the concept that some problems can be solved by breaking them into smaller versions of themselves (recursion conceptually, not yet in code). Example: "To find the largest number in a list, find the larger of the first number and the max of the rest." They understand the base case and recursive case but don't yet implement it in code (that's a high school topic).

borderline.title: Write and test pseudocode for a non-trivial algorithm
borderline.short_name: Design and verify an algorithm with pseudocode
borderline.description: Students design pseudocode for a more complex algorithm (e.g., finding a median, checking if a number is prime, or simulating a simple game turn), then trace it with multiple test cases to verify correctness.

borderline.title: Analyze and improve an algorithm's representation
borderline.short_name: Optimize how an algorithm is represented
borderline.description: Students are given an algorithm in one form (e.g., a verbose pseudocode) and are asked to improve its clarity or efficiency by refactoring its representation (e.g., shortening pseudocode, simplifying a flowchart, or adding comments to code).

borderline.title: Monte Carlo simulations with loops
borderline.short_name: Estimate probabilities using loops
borderline.description: Students design loop‑based simulations that approximate probabilities (e.g., estimate chance of rolling a sum ≥ 9 with two dice) and interpret the results in terms of experimental vs theoretical probability.

borderline.title: Implement a sorting algorithm (bubble sort or selection sort)
borderline.short_name: Write a sorting algorithm
borderline.description: Students implement a complete sorting algorithm (not just swap intuition, but the full loop logic) to sort a list or table by a numeric or alphabetic criterion, understanding algorithmic complexity informally (e.g., "this takes many comparisons").

borderline.title: Document and analyze a complete game system
borderline.short_name: Explain game architecture and design choices
borderline.description: Students document their game: architecture diagram showing how systems connect, pseudocode or flowcharts for key algorithms, and written explanations of design choices (why they chose certain collision detection, what difficulty parameters they used, how enemy AI works). This reinforces reflection and communication of complex ideas.

borderline.title: Evaluate and mitigate bias in AI detection systems
borderline.short_name: Test and reduce bias in AI
borderline.description: Students build or use a pose/gesture/speech detection system and systematically test it across different demographic groups, lighting conditions, accents, etc. They measure and document disparities in accuracy and propose mitigations.

borderline.title: Estimate probability using large-scale simulation or real data
borderline.short_name: Estimate odds from data
borderline.description: Students estimate the probability of a complex or uncertain event (e.g., a hurricane, a sports outcome) by analyzing historical data or running a sophisticated Monte Carlo simulation with many variables, integrating lists, loops, and conditional logic.

borderline.title: Analyze bias in AI models trained on biased data
borderline.short_name: How does biased data hurt AI?
borderline.description: Students learn that AI systems trained on biased datasets produce biased outputs, and can examine examples (e.g., if a training dataset has more images of one gender, the model may perform worse on that gender). They reason about consequences and potential fixes.

borderline.title: Historical disparities in computing access and benefits
borderline.short_name: Who benefits from computing? Who doesn't?
borderline.description: Students analyze historical patterns showing how computing benefits and access have been distributed unequally across groups (gender disparities in tech careers, digital divides by geography and socioeconomic status, bias in AI training data, underrepresentation of women and people of color in computing). They connect history to present-day inequities.

all_priority_skills.title: Recognize and apply common algorithm patterns (search, sort, accumulate)
all_priority_skills.description: Students learn to recognize and name common algorithmic patterns: linear search (find first matching item), simple sort (reorder items), accumulation (collect sums or counts), and simulation (repeat action with updates). When given a problem, they choose the appropriate pattern.

all_priority_skills.title: Understand why different algorithms are chosen for different problems
all_priority_skills.short_name: Choose the right algorithm for the task
all_priority_skills.description: Given a problem, students consider multiple possible algorithms and justify which is most appropriate based on efficiency, clarity, or fit. Example: Why use a specific sorting algorithm over repeated swaps? Why use binary search instead of linear? This develops algorithmic decision-making.

all_priority_skills.title: Represent an algorithm in pseudocode or text code
all_priority_skills.description: Students transition from block-based code to pseudocode or simple text-based code representation. They write an algorithm in plain language with code-like structure (e.g., "for each item in list: if item > max, set max = item"). This bridges to more formal programming.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze an algorithm for correctness on edge cases
all_priority_skills.short_name: Test an algorithm on tricky inputs
all_priority_skills.description: Students test an algorithm (given in code or pseudocode) on edge cases (empty input, single item, maximum/minimum values, repeats) and identify if it fails and why. This develops rigorous thinking about algorithm robustness.

all_priority_skills.title: Trace an algorithm with state changes over time
all_priority_skills.short_name: Trace a simulation algorithm step by step
all_priority_skills.description: Students trace an algorithm that simulates a process or system over multiple timesteps (e.g., a ball rolling, a population growing, or a search process narrowing), tracking state changes and predicting behavior at future steps.

all_priority_skills.title: Design a flowchart for a sorting or search algorithm
all_priority_skills.short_name: Create a flowchart for finding or organizing data
all_priority_skills.description: Students create a flowchart for a simple algorithmic task such as linear search, bubble sort, or selection sort, using appropriate decision points and loops to represent the logic.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze algorithm complexity and steps required
all_priority_skills.short_name: Count steps in algorithms and compare efficiency
all_priority_skills.description: Students analyze two algorithms that solve the same problem and count or estimate the number of steps (or time complexity in intuitive terms) each requires for different input sizes, reasoning about which is more efficient.

all_priority_skills.title: Trace an algorithm and identify a bug or edge case
all_priority_skills.description: Students trace an algorithm (in pseudocode or code) with specific inputs, identify a case where it produces an incorrect result, and explain why (e.g., "When the list is empty, it crashes" or "When the target is at the end, it takes too long").

all_priority_skills.title: Representation Tradeoffs: Detail vs. Simplicity
all_priority_skills.description: Students analyze and evaluate tradeoffs between different data representations: detailed vs. simple, accurate vs. usable, precise vs. understandable. They examine real examples (e.g., weather forecasts, nutritional labels, maps) and discuss: What information is emphasized? What is hidden or simplified? Who benefits from this representation? They learn that representation choices involve tradeoffs and reflect priorities.

all_priority_skills.title: Design a multi-stage simulation plan
all_priority_skills.description: Students design a detailed plan for a simulation (e.g., ecosystem, physics, or social dynamics) that breaks it into components (agents, rules, interactions, data collection) and stages (setup, run, analyze). They learn systems thinking.

all_priority_skills.title: Use XO to brainstorm and structure a game design document
all_priority_skills.short_name: Create a GDD with XO help
all_priority_skills.description: Students use XO to brainstorm and structure a formal Game Design Document (GDD) for a moderately complex game (mechanics, level progression, art style, story beats). They learn a professional planning format while leveraging AI.

all_priority_skills.title: Decompose a data-driven app into models and views
all_priority_skills.short_name: Separate data and UI in a plan
all_priority_skills.description: Students plan an interactive data app (e.g., a leaderboard dashboard, quiz show, or survey tool) and explicitly separate the data model (what data is stored) from the UI (how it's displayed and interacted with). This teaches architectural decomposition.

all_priority_skills.title: Identify and fix poor decomposition in a plan
all_priority_skills.short_name: Find and improve bad design choices
all_priority_skills.description: Students review a project plan that has poor decomposition (e.g., all code in one sprite, no separation between logic and UI, unclear dependencies) and suggest improvements to make it more modular and maintainable.

all_priority_skills.title: Recognize iteration patterns in different contexts
all_priority_skills.short_name: Spot loop patterns in simulations and games
all_priority_skills.description: Students identify the iteration patterns underlying common game and simulation behaviors (e.g., "update physics every frame," "process each sprite," "check all collisions"), understanding that iteration is a fundamental building block.

all_priority_skills.title: Design composite algorithms using smaller algorithmic patterns
all_priority_skills.description: Students design a solution to a complex problem by recognizing that it can be decomposed into smaller, standard algorithmic patterns (e.g., a search pattern + an accumulator pattern) and combining them.

all_priority_skills.title: Optimize code by eliminating redundant patterns
all_priority_skills.short_name: Simplify code by removing repeated patterns
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine an existing project with redundant patterns and systematically refactor it, combining loops, nesting, and custom blocks to minimize duplication and improve clarity.

all_priority_skills.title: Explain how pattern recognition leads to better algorithm design
all_priority_skills.description: Students articulate how recognizing patterns in a problem (or in existing solutions) leads to better algorithm design, including improved efficiency, readability, and generalizability.

all_priority_skills.title: Accessibility audit and remediation
all_priority_skills.description: Students audit an existing program (CreatiCode project or a web app) against an accessibility checklist (readable text, keyboard navigation, color contrast, alt text for images, clear instructions). They identify gaps and propose or implement fixes.

all_priority_skills.title: Identify and mitigate potential harms in a design
all_priority_skills.short_name: What could go wrong? Prevent harms.
all_priority_skills.description: Students brainstorm potential negative impacts or unintended consequences of a program they've designed (e.g., "My game is addictive and kids might play too long," "My chatbot gives wrong answers"). They identify one harm and propose a mitigation strategy (e.g., add a play-time limit, add a disclaimer, verify sources).

all_priority_skills.title: Gather iterative feedback across multiple rounds
all_priority_skills.description: Students conduct 2–3 rounds of user testing on a program they're developing. After each round, they analyze feedback, make changes, and test again. They document how the program evolves and reflect on insights gained.

all_priority_skills.title: Design a simulation for a real-world question
all_priority_skills.short_name: Simulation to answer a research question
all_priority_skills.description: Students design and build a simulation to answer a real-world or classroom question (e.g., "How does population grow if there's limited food?" or "What happens to a virus spreading in a population?"). They define what to model, run the simulation, and interpret results.

all_priority_skills.title: Use loops to simulate motion over time
all_priority_skills.description: Students implement a loop that repeatedly updates position (and optionally velocity) to simulate motion, such as an object sliding or falling with a simple rule each step.

all_priority_skills.title: Nested loops for 2D grids and tile maps
all_priority_skills.description: Students use two loops to process a conceptual 2D grid (e.g., rows and columns of tiles), even if represented as positions or a 1D list plus indices, introducing matrix‑like reasoning.

all_priority_skills.title: Compare loop algorithms by counting steps
all_priority_skills.description: Students compare two loop‑based solutions that both solve the same problem but use different numbers of iterations (e.g., repeated subtraction vs direct arithmetic) and reason about which is more efficient for larger inputs.

all_priority_skills.title: Loop patterns for counting and accumulation
all_priority_skills.description: Students identify and/or construct loops that follow common accumulator patterns (counting, summing, tracking min/max), distinguishing them from unrelated code.

all_priority_skills.title: Use conditionals to implement a state machine
all_priority_skills.description: Students use if/else blocks to track and transition between program states (e.g., menu → playing → game over → restart). They understand how conditionals drive state changes.

all_priority_skills.title: Handle edge cases and boundary conditions
all_priority_skills.description: Students write conditionals that handle boundary and edge cases (e.g., "if score == 0", "if x < 0 or x > screen_width"), preventing bugs or unexpected behavior.

all_priority_skills.title: Write conditionals for pattern recognition or rule-checking
all_priority_skills.description: Students use if statements to detect patterns or check membership (e.g., "if this word is in my list of banned words", "if the sequence is ascending"). This applies conditionals to data validation and pattern detection.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze and compare conditional logic approaches
all_priority_skills.description: Students compare two different conditional implementations of the same algorithm (e.g., using nested if vs a switch-like structure) and reason about clarity, efficiency, and maintainability.

all_priority_skills.title: Use variables to store and update state in simulations
all_priority_skills.description: Students create simulations (e.g., population, weather, particle motion) where variables represent state (position, velocity, count) and expressions update them each time step, demonstrating how variables enable temporal processes.

all_priority_skills.title: Use aggregate expressions (sum, average, min, max)
all_priority_skills.description: Students write expressions or use blocks to compute aggregate statistics (sum, average, minimum, maximum) over variables or lists, connecting expressions to data analysis.

all_priority_skills.title: Use variables in conditional logic with compound conditions
all_priority_skills.description: Students create conditional expressions using logical operators (AND, OR, NOT) to combine multiple variable comparisons, enabling more nuanced decision logic.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze how variable updates affect program behavior
all_priority_skills.description: Students reason about how changing variable initialization values, update rates, or expressions changes the program's output or behavior, supporting algorithmic analysis.

all_priority_skills.title: Design and populate a table for a real-world inventory or database
all_priority_skills.short_name: Create a data model for real-world data
all_priority_skills.description: Students design the structure of a table (columns and data types) to model a real-world domain (e.g., a library catalog, game inventory, sports statistics) and populate it with realistic data.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze a dataset to find patterns or outliers
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a table of data and use code to find patterns (e.g., the most common value, a trend over time) or identify outliers (unusual values). They may create summary statistics or visualizations.

all_priority_skills.title: Transform or clean data in a table using loops and conditions
all_priority_skills.description: Students perform data cleaning operations: remove rows with missing values, standardize formats (e.g., uppercase names), fix errors, or handle special cases—preparing raw data for analysis.

all_priority_skills.title: Use nested loops to analyze relationships between two datasets
all_priority_skills.description: Students write nested loops to compare or correlate data from two tables (e.g., matching purchases to customer profiles, checking for correlations in sensor readings), identifying connections or anomalies.

all_priority_skills.title: Represent numbers at different precision levels
all_priority_skills.description: Students explore how the precision of numeric data affects storage and meaning (e.g., rounding 3.14159 to 3.14, storing temperature to the nearest degree vs. tenth), understanding trade-offs.

all_priority_skills.title: Use nested data structures to represent complex information
all_priority_skills.short_name: Store complex data in lists and tables
all_priority_skills.description: Students create or work with nested structures (e.g., a list of tables, where each table represents a player with multiple attributes) to model real-world complexity.

all_priority_skills.title: Evaluate the appropriateness of a data type for a task
all_priority_skills.description: Students analyze a project scenario and make evidence-based decisions about what data types to use, considering what operations will be needed and what values are expected.

all_priority_skills.title: Handle missing or invalid data in a program
all_priority_skills.short_name: Deal with incomplete or wrong data
all_priority_skills.description: Students write code that gracefully handles missing values (e.g., a player with no high score) or invalid input, understanding data quality issues.

all_priority_skills.title: Compare storage and efficiency of different data representations
all_priority_skills.short_name: Choose efficient ways to store data
all_priority_skills.description: Students compare two ways of representing the same information (e.g., storing 5 items as individual variables vs. a list, or as a single tally number) and reason about efficiency and clarity.

all_priority_skills.title: Formulate a clear, testable data question
all_priority_skills.description: Students formulate a specific data question that can be answered by collecting and analyzing data, distinguishing it from questions answered by opinion or general knowledge. Examples: "Do taller students jump higher?" "Which type of music gets the most plays in our class?"

all_priority_skills.title: Collect data systematically using lists and tables
all_priority_skills.description: Students execute a planned data collection (20-50 data points across 3-4 columns), recording data into a CreatiCode table or list. They maintain data quality by following consistent procedures.

all_priority_skills.title: Manipulate data with code (filter, sort, aggregate)
all_priority_skills.short_name: Process data using loops and conditions
all_priority_skills.description: Students write code that reads from a table or list, applies filters (keep only rows where a condition is true) or sorts (arrange by a column), or calculates aggregates (sum, average, count) to prepare data for analysis.

all_priority_skills.title: Identify and correct data quality issues
all_priority_skills.description: Students systematically review collected data, identify specific quality issues (duplicates, out-of-range values, inconsistent units, missing entries), and apply appropriate fixes. They document what was wrong and how they fixed it.

all_priority_skills.title: Draw simple conclusions from organized data
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine their collected and cleaned dataset and use it to answer the original data question. They identify the most common value, the largest/smallest, trends, or comparisons between groups, and state a simple conclusion.

all_priority_skills.title: Simulate data collection and compute statistics
all_priority_skills.short_name: Run simulations and analyze the results
all_priority_skills.description: Students create a loop-based simulation (e.g., simulating a chance experiment, rolling dice, or surveying random responses) and track results in a list or tally variables. They then analyze the simulated data (compute average, count outcomes) to estimate probabilities or expected values.

all_priority_skills.title: Identify and describe bias in data collection
all_priority_skills.short_name: Spot bias in how data was collected
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a data-collection scenario (e.g., a survey conducted only at recess, a sample that doesn't represent everyone) and identify potential sources of bias. They explain how bias might skew the results.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze trends over time and make predictions
all_priority_skills.short_name: Follow trends to predict future values
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a time-series chart (e.g., daily temperature, monthly website visits, population growth) and describe the trend. They then make a reasonable prediction about what will happen next (e.g., "The temperature has been rising each day; it will probably rise again tomorrow").

all_priority_skills.title: Compare distributions of data
all_priority_skills.short_name: Compare shape and spread of two datasets
all_priority_skills.description: Students compare two datasets (e.g., two classes' test scores, rainfall in two cities) by looking at their distributions: shape (skew, symmetry), center (mean or median), and spread (range, variability). They describe which dataset is more consistent or has more extreme values.

all_priority_skills.title: Conduct a full multi-step experiment with hypothesis
all_priority_skills.short_name: Test a hypothesis with an experiment
all_priority_skills.description: Students formulate a clear hypothesis (prediction), design an experiment to test it (with controls, variables, and sample size decisions), collect data, and draw conclusions, practicing the scientific method within a probability or observational context.

all_priority_skills.title: Implement a Monte Carlo simulation to estimate a probability
all_priority_skills.short_name: Run 1000s of trials to estimate odds
all_priority_skills.description: Students code a simulation using a large number of iterations (e.g., 1000 or 10,000 trials) to empirically estimate a complex probability (e.g., chance of rolling three dice that sum to 10, or chance of at least two people sharing a birthday in a room of 20). They interpret the frequency as a probability estimate.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze sources of bias in data collection and its impact
all_priority_skills.short_name: How did bias affect the results?
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a real or simulated dataset known to have bias (e.g., results from a survey taken only online, results from a controlled experiment run only in one location), analyze how the bias occurred, and reason about how the results would differ if the bias were eliminated.

all_priority_skills.title: Conduct a sampling experiment and compare to population parameter
all_priority_skills.short_name: Does your sample match the whole group?
all_priority_skills.description: Students take multiple random samples from a known population (real or simulated), compute a statistic (e.g., mean, proportion) for each sample, and compare sample statistics to the true population parameter, building intuition about sampling variability and estimators.

all_priority_skills.title: Pre‑process text for analysis
all_priority_skills.description: Students perform multiple preprocessing steps on text (remove punctuation, convert to lowercase, trim spaces, remove common words) to prepare it for analysis or AI processing, learning data cleaning for text.

all_priority_skills.title: Compute text similarity or comparison
all_priority_skills.short_name: Compare how similar two texts are
all_priority_skills.description: Students use AI or string matching logic to assess similarity between two text passages, learning that text similarity can be computed and compared.

all_priority_skills.title:
Use AI to answer questions based on a text passage

- **Smart Retrieval:** Ask AI questions about text
- **Description:** Students use a ChatGPT prompt that provides context (e.g., a passage) and asks a question about it, learning how AI can retrieve and synthesize information from text.
- **Challenge format:** Coding, question‑answering project. Provided: a passage. Students ask ChatGPT: "Based on this text: [passage], what is [question]?" and process the response. Auto‑grading checks answer validity against expected responses.
- **CSTA:** MS‑PRO‑PF‑01, CAS‑ET‑05 (Emerging technologies in innovative ways).

### T29.G7.04 – Reflect on bias and fairness in text data and AI responses
all_priority_skills.short_name: Think about bias in text and AI
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine how text datasets or AI models might reflect or introduce bias, learning critical thinking about text processing and AI fairness.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze unintended systemic impacts of a technology
all_priority_skills.short_name: How does one technology change everything?
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine how a single technology can create ripple effects across society (e.g., smartphones enabling communication but also job displacement in certain sectors, social media enabling connection but also affecting mental health). They map systems and second-order effects.

all_priority_skills.title: Evaluate equity and access across communities
all_priority_skills.short_name: Do all communities benefit equally from a technology?
all_priority_skills.description: Students research or analyze whether access to and benefits from a technology (e.g., broadband, AI tools, smartphones) are equally distributed, and what happens when some communities lack access.

all_priority_skills.title: Examine the environmental life cycle of a technology
all_priority_skills.short_name: The full environmental impact of a device
all_priority_skills.description: Students trace the full environmental lifecycle of a computing device: extraction of materials, manufacturing, shipping, use, and disposal/recycling. They quantify or estimate the carbon footprint and waste.

all_priority_skills.title: Propose a technology solution with ethical considerations
all_priority_skills.description: Students propose a new technology (or improve an existing one) to solve a real problem while considering potential negative effects, equity, environmental impact, and privacy. They justify their approach.

all_priority_skills.title: How tech transforms industries and jobs
all_priority_skills.short_name: Analyze how technology changes careers and industries
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a specific industry (agriculture, manufacturing, healthcare, entertainment) and trace how computing and automation have changed the jobs available, the skills needed, and the opportunities for workers. They consider both positive changes (new careers) and challenges (job displacement, need for retraining).

all_priority_skills.title: Ethical evaluation of emerging technologies
all_priority_skills.short_name: Evaluate a new technology for ethics and fairness
all_priority_skills.description: Students select an emerging technology (AI, VR, IoT, blockchain, autonomous vehicles, facial recognition) and conduct a thorough ethical evaluation: What is it designed to do? Who benefits? Who might be harmed? Is it fair? Is it accessible? What policies should govern it?

all_priority_skills.title: Lead a team project with clear communication
all_priority_skills.short_name: Manage a collaborative project from start to finish
all_priority_skills.description: Students take on a leadership role in a multi-person, multi-week CreatiCode project. They practice planning (breaking tasks into steps, assigning roles), communicating clearly (holding meetings, writing updates), managing time and conflicts, and presenting results professionally.

all_priority_skills.title: Reflect on fairness in your team and project
all_priority_skills.short_name: Assess your team's inclusivity and your project's fairness
all_priority_skills.description: Students reflect on two aspects: (1) Did our team work fairly—did everyone contribute, were decisions made inclusively, was credit given? (2) Is our project inclusive and fair—does it include diverse characters, avoid stereotypes, work well for people with different abilities?

all_priority_skills.title: Design an algorithm for a simulation or model
all_priority_skills.short_name: Create an algorithm to simulate a process
all_priority_skills.description: Students design an algorithm that simulates a real-world process or system (e.g., a predator-prey ecosystem, weather patterns with simple rules, or traffic flow). The algorithm repeatedly updates state and checks conditions to model behavior over time. This applies algorithmic thinking to simulation.

all_priority_skills.title: Understand recursion conceptually (algorithm calling itself)
all_priority_skills.description: Students encounter the concept that some problems can be solved by breaking them into smaller versions of themselves (recursion conceptually, not yet in code). Example: "To find the largest number in a list, find the larger of the first number and the max of the rest." They understand the base case and recursive case but don't yet implement it in code (that's a high school topic).

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze the impact of an algorithm on society or individuals
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a real-world algorithmic system (e.g., social media recommendation, search rankings, college admission scoring) and analyze its societal impacts. They consider who benefits, who might be harmed, ethical implications, and possible improvements.

all_priority_skills.title: Refactor a complex algorithm for clarity or efficiency
all_priority_skills.description: Given a working but convoluted or inefficient algorithm (in block or text code), students refactor it to be clearer, more modular, or more efficient. Example: breaking a long script into named procedures, extracting repeated logic into a loop, or optimizing a search to avoid redundant checks.

all_priority_skills.title: Write and test pseudocode for a non-trivial algorithm
all_priority_skills.short_name: Design and verify an algorithm with pseudocode
all_priority_skills.description: Students design pseudocode for a more complex algorithm (e.g., finding a median, checking if a number is prime, or simulating a simple game turn), then trace it with multiple test cases to verify correctness.

all_priority_skills.title: Create a flowchart for a decision-making process
all_priority_skills.short_name: Design a flowchart for a real-world decision
all_priority_skills.description: Students create a flowchart that models a real-world decision process (e.g., "Should I play outside?" with branches based on weather, temperature, and homework done, or "How to choose a book" based on genre and length preferences). This shows algorithm thinking applied to everyday reasoning.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze and improve an algorithm's representation
all_priority_skills.short_name: Optimize how an algorithm is represented
all_priority_skills.description: Students are given an algorithm in one form (e.g., a verbose pseudocode) and are asked to improve its clarity or efficiency by refactoring its representation (e.g., shortening pseudocode, simplifying a flowchart, or adding comments to code).

all_priority_skills.title: Compare deterministic and probabilistic algorithms
all_priority_skills.short_name: Trace algorithms with and without randomness
all_priority_skills.description: Students trace two versions of an algorithm—one deterministic (same input always produces same output) and one probabilistic (uses randomness)—and articulate the differences, advantages, and disadvantages of each approach.

all_priority_skills.title: Feature Vectors for AI Classification
all_priority_skills.description: Students create feature vectors to represent data for an AI classification task. For example, representing animals for classification: [has_fur: 1, number_of_legs: 4, can_fly: 0, habitat: 'land']. They understand that: (1) AI needs data in numerical/categorical format, (2) choosing the right features is crucial for AI performance, (3) some features are more informative than others, and (4) representation affects what the AI can learn. This bridges representation to machine learning.

all_priority_skills.title: Plan a multi-feature interactive app with XO
all_priority_skills.short_name: Design a complex app with AI guidance
all_priority_skills.description: Students use XO to help plan a large project with multiple interconnected features (e.g., a learning app with lessons, quizzes, progress tracking, and a leaderboard). They create a detailed architecture plan showing data flow, feature modules, and dependencies.

all_priority_skills.title: Create a formal project specification document
all_priority_skills.description: Students create a formal specification document for a non-trivial project, including requirements, system architecture, component descriptions, data schemas, and testing strategy. This mimics industry-standard documentation.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze project complexity and estimate effort
all_priority_skills.description: Students read project plans of varying ambition and estimate the relative effort and risk (e.g., "This plan requires 5 different sprites and complex collision—it's a 6-week project." vs "This is simpler, maybe 2 weeks."). They learn to realistically assess scope.

all_priority_skills.title: Refactor a large codebase into modules
all_priority_skills.description: Students take a moderately complex, working program (e.g., a game with 200+ blocks) and refactor it by extracting repeated logic into custom blocks, separating concerns across sprites, and adding documentation. This is a real-world refactoring task.

all_priority_skills.title: Recognize and leverage common algorithmic patterns
all_priority_skills.short_name: Use standard algorithm patterns in solutions
all_priority_skills.description: Students identify standard algorithmic patterns (e.g., linear search, accumulation, two‑pointer, divide‑and‑conquer) in problem descriptions and apply them effectively to solve problems, understanding that many problems can be solved by pattern matching to known solutions.

all_priority_skills.title: Design modular, reusable custom blocks for a project
all_priority_skills.short_name: Build a library of procedures for a project
all_priority_skills.description: Students design and build a suite of well‑named, well‑documented custom blocks (procedures) for a project, recognizing that good abstractions make code easier to reason about, test, and reuse across multiple scenes or game states.

all_priority_skills.title: Generalize a specific solution into a parameterized template
all_priority_skills.short_name: Turn a solution into a template others can reuse
all_priority_skills.description: Students take a working solution to a specific problem (e.g., a quiz with five questions) and generalize it into a reusable template with parameters (e.g., `make_quiz(num_questions, question_list)`) that others can adapt for different inputs, learning that good design anticipates reuse.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze and justify choices in pattern‑based design
all_priority_skills.short_name: Explain trade‑offs in abstraction and reuse
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a project and argue about design choices (e.g., "Should this be a custom block or inline code?" "Is this parameter necessary?"). They weigh factors like code length, clarity, flexibility, and performance in the context of the problem.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze potential biases in an algorithm or design
all_priority_skills.short_name: Find and fix biases in your design
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine an algorithm or program they've designed and identify potential biases (e.g., does it work equally well for all genders, abilities, or backgrounds?). They propose and implement changes to mitigate bias (e.g., diverse imagery, inclusive language, accessible features).

all_priority_skills.title: Design for diverse audiences with conflicting needs
all_priority_skills.short_name: Serve multiple user groups with different needs
all_priority_skills.description: Students design a program or algorithm that must satisfy two or more distinct user groups with potentially conflicting needs (e.g., "A math game for 2nd graders AND their parents," "A website for English learners AND native speakers"). They document trade-offs and design decisions that balance needs.

all_priority_skills.title: Run a controlled simulation experiment
all_priority_skills.description: Students build a simulation, then systematically vary one parameter at a time (e.g., starting population, food availability) and observe effects on outcomes. They document hypotheses, results, and conclusions. This teaches simulation as a tool for experimentation and evidence-based reasoning.

all_priority_skills.title: Evaluate realism and limitations in a simulation
all_priority_skills.description: Students critically examine a simulation they've built or studied and evaluate its realism and limitations. They identify simplifications, assumptions, and edge cases not covered. They articulate how limitations might affect conclusions drawn from the simulation.

all_priority_skills.title: Monte Carlo simulations with loops
all_priority_skills.description: Students design loop‑based simulations that approximate probabilities (e.g., estimate chance of rolling a sum ≥ 9 with two dice) and interpret the results in terms of experimental vs theoretical probability.

all_priority_skills.title: Implement iterative algorithms with loops
all_priority_skills.description: Students implement simple iterative algorithms that rely on loops and repeated updates, such as computing the greatest common divisor by repeated subtraction or checking if a number is prime by trying divisors.

all_priority_skills.title: Process structured data with nested loops
all_priority_skills.description: Students use nested loops to process 2D‑structured data (e.g., a list encoding grid values, or two parallel lists) and compute statistics like row/column sums or counts of certain cells.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze and justify loop designs
all_priority_skills.short_name: Explain loop choices for a task
all_priority_skills.description: Students analyze given loop‑based solutions (e.g., using `repeat until` vs a counted `repeat` with a condition inside) and justify which structure is more appropriate or reliable for a given task. They articulate reasons using input ranges, stopping conditions, and readability.

all_priority_skills.title: Implement multi-stage game or simulation logic
all_priority_skills.description: Students design conditional logic for a multi-stage game or simulation (e.g., tutorial → levels 1-3 → boss battle → game over, each with different rule sets). They manage transitions and state-specific behavior.

all_priority_skills.title: Use conditionals to validate and sanitize input data
all_priority_skills.description: Students write if statements that validate user input (e.g., "if the input is not a number, show error message"; "if the age is < 0 or > 150, reject and ask again"). This applies conditional logic to data integrity.

all_priority_skills.title: Process and make decisions on structured data with nested conditionals
all_priority_skills.description: Students use nested or chained conditionals to traverse a decision tree or make hierarchical decisions on data (e.g., categorizing users by age and spending, or classifying items by multiple attributes).

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze and document the logic of conditional algorithms
all_priority_skills.description: Students analyze a conditional algorithm, document its decision logic (often via a flowchart or comment), and justify why specific conditions are needed.

all_priority_skills.title: Use variables in iterative algorithms
all_priority_skills.description: Students implement algorithms (e.g., searching, sorting, iterative numerical methods) that rely on variables to track state across many iterations, such as a variable tracking the index in a search or the accumulator in a repeated approximation.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze expressions for efficiency and correctness
all_priority_skills.description: Students compare different expressions or variable strategies that solve the same problem (e.g., computing a sum by repeated addition vs direct formula) and reason about correctness, readability, and efficiency.

all_priority_skills.title: Use variables in data collection and statistical analysis
all_priority_skills.description: Students use variables (or lists of variables) to collect data from user input or sensors, compute statistics on the data, and use those statistics in expressions to make decisions or report findings.

all_priority_skills.title: Debug variable-related logical errors
all_priority_skills.description: Students identify and fix bugs related to variable scope, initialization order, incorrect update expressions, or misuse of variables in conditionals. Debugging is more sophisticated, involving tracing across multiple blocks or loops.

all_priority_skills.title: Use expressions to implement mathematical or logical rules
all_priority_skills.description: Students take mathematical formulas or logical rules (e.g., distance = speed × time, tax = price × rate, is_valid = age >= 18 AND has_id) and translate them into variable assignments and expressions in code.

all_priority_skills.title: Implement a data structure using lists (simple version of array of records)
all_priority_skills.short_name: Build a data structure with lists
all_priority_skills.description: Students implement a simple record or struct-like behavior using multiple parallel lists or a list of lists, simulating how professional code organizes complex data.

all_priority_skills.title: Implement a sorting algorithm (bubble sort or selection sort)
all_priority_skills.description: Students implement a complete sorting algorithm (not just swap intuition, but the full loop logic) to sort a list or table by a numeric or alphabetic criterion, understanding algorithmic complexity informally (e.g., "this takes many comparisons").

all_priority_skills.title: Build a simulation using list-based state
all_priority_skills.short_name: Simulate a system with list data
all_priority_skills.description: Students create a simulation (e.g., a game, a population model, a traffic system) where entities and their properties are stored in lists or tables, and the simulation loop reads/updates this data each frame.

all_priority_skills.title: Query and report statistics from a complex dataset
all_priority_skills.short_name: Analyze a real dataset with code
all_priority_skills.description: Students load or are provided a realistic multi-column table (e.g., weather data, sports statistics, survey results) and write code to compute requested statistics: means, medians, percentiles, counts by category, trends, or comparisons.

all_priority_skills.title: Model real-world relationships using table joins or lookups
all_priority_skills.short_name: Manage related data in a program
all_priority_skills.description: Students use lists or tables to model entities and relationships (e.g., students with associated grades, orders with associated items), and write code to perform lookups or join operations to answer queries (e.g., "What grades does student X have?").

all_priority_skills.title: Design a complete data schema for a project
all_priority_skills.description: Students design a detailed plan for what data a project will store, including all variable types, relationships, and constraints (e.g., "score must be non-negative," "player name is required").

all_priority_skills.title: Recognize bias and limitations in data representation
all_priority_skills.short_name: Think critically about how data is encoded
all_priority_skills.description: Students explore how choices in data representation can introduce bias or lose important information (e.g., representing gender as only "boy" or "girl," categorizing ages into broad ranges, using single-language labels).

all_priority_skills.title: Use advanced data structures for algorithms
all_priority_skills.description: Students select appropriate data structures (lists, tables, or dictionaries) for an algorithmic task, understanding that the choice affects how efficiently the program can search, sort, or process data.

all_priority_skills.title: Explore how data type mismatches cause errors
all_priority_skills.description: Students encounter and fix programs where incorrect operations are performed on wrong data types (e.g., adding the text "5" to the number 10, or trying to sort mixed data types incorrectly), understanding type constraints.

all_priority_skills.title: Evaluate how data representation affects real-world decisions
all_priority_skills.description: Students analyze real-world scenarios where data representation choices have consequences (e.g., how credit scores are calculated, how student grades are recorded, how census categories are defined) and discuss ethical implications.

all_priority_skills.title: Design an ethical data collection process
all_priority_skills.description: Students design a data collection for a research question while considering ethical issues: privacy (what personal data is necessary), consent (asking permission to collect data), fairness (including diverse participants, avoiding bias), and transparency (telling people what their data will be used for).

all_priority_skills.title: Execute a complete data investigation (question to analysis)
all_priority_skills.description: Students execute an end-to-end data investigation: ask a testable question, collect 30-100 data points across multiple attributes, organize into a table, clean the data, filter/aggregate as needed, analyze to answer the question, and write a brief summary of findings and any limitations.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze relationships between variables in data
all_priority_skills.description: Students work with a multi-column dataset and analyze relationships between variables (e.g., "Do students who read more books also have higher vocabulary scores?" or "Is there a pattern between hours of screen time and sleep quality?"). They use filtering, sorting, or visual inspection to identify patterns.

all_priority_skills.title: Recognize bias and limitations in data collection
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a dataset or a data collection process and identify potential biases (e.g., sampling only from one school excludes other communities, asking questions on an app excludes people without internet) and limitations (e.g., small sample size, measurements taken at only one time). They reflect on how these affect conclusions.

all_priority_skills.title: Use cloud storage or multiplayer data to conduct group research
all_priority_skills.description: Students work in a group to collect data where each member contributes to a shared table or list (using CreatiCode's cloud or multiplayer blocks), then collectively analyze the combined dataset. This introduces collaborative data science and networked data collection.

all_priority_skills.title: Design and conduct a simple data investigation
all_priority_skills.short_name: Ask a question, collect, analyze, and conclude
all_priority_skills.description: Students develop a data question, design a collection method, gather data using CreatiCode (e.g., a survey project, simulation, or sensor logging), organize and analyze the data (computing summaries and visualizations), and write a conclusion supported by the data.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze two variables for potential causal relationships
all_priority_skills.short_name: Explore whether one variable affects another
all_priority_skills.description: Students investigate whether a relationship between two variables suggests causation (e.g., does study time cause higher test scores?) or is merely correlation. They consider alternative explanations and limitations of the data.

all_priority_skills.title: Create an interactive data dashboard
all_priority_skills.short_name: Build a tool to explore data with controls
all_priority_skills.description: Students use CreatiCode widgets (sliders, buttons, dropdowns) to build an interactive dashboard that displays filtered or grouped data, allowing users to adjust parameters and see updated visualizations. This combines data analysis with UI design.

all_priority_skills.title: Evaluate and justify data-driven conclusions
all_priority_skills.short_name: Support a conclusion with data evidence
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a data-driven conclusion or argument (e.g., "Our school should extend recess because students are happier") and evaluate it critically: Is the data sufficient? Is the conclusion justified? What alternative explanations exist? What data would strengthen or weaken the argument?

all_priority_skills.title: Design and conduct an experiment addressing a real question
all_priority_skills.short_name: Run an experiment to answer your question
all_priority_skills.description: Students develop their own research question, design an experiment or survey to answer it (including decisions about variables, controls, sample size, and data collection method), conduct the experiment, analyze results, and communicate findings. This is a capstone skill integrating earlier concepts.

all_priority_skills.title: Estimate probability using large-scale simulation or real data
all_priority_skills.description: Students estimate the probability of a complex or uncertain event (e.g., a hurricane, a sports outcome) by analyzing historical data or running a sophisticated Monte Carlo simulation with many variables, integrating lists, loops, and conditional logic.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze bias in AI models trained on biased data
all_priority_skills.short_name: How does biased data hurt AI?
all_priority_skills.description: Students learn that AI systems trained on biased datasets produce biased outputs, and can examine examples (e.g., if a training dataset has more images of one gender, the model may perform worse on that gender). They reason about consequences and potential fixes.

all_priority_skills.title: Evaluate ethical considerations in data-driven decisions
all_priority_skills.short_name: Is it fair to decide this way?
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine a real-world scenario where a decision is made using data (e.g., hiring, lending, school admissions, content recommendation) and analyze ethical concerns: Is the data biased? Will the decision harm some groups? What are privacy implications? Should people be informed and given agency?

all_priority_skills.title: Build a keyword search and retrieval system
all_priority_skills.description: Students design a project that takes user input (keywords) and searches a collection of text documents (or passages in a list), returning matching documents. This is a simplified version of real search engines.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze sentiment or emotion in multiple texts using AI
all_priority_skills.description: Students apply an AI model (via ChatGPT) to analyze sentiment or emotion in a batch of text samples, then aggregate and visualize the results (e.g., how many positive, negative, neutral texts are in the set).

all_priority_skills.title: Extract entities or relationships from text using AI
all_priority_skills.short_name: Find names and connections in text
all_priority_skills.description: Students use AI (ChatGPT) to extract named entities (people, places, organizations) or relationships from text, learning that AI can identify and structure information from unstructured text.

all_priority_skills.title: Evaluate the ethical implications of text processing and NLP
all_priority_skills.description: Students analyze and discuss complex issues: how NLP systems might perpetuate biases, privacy concerns with text collection, and the use of NLP in surveillance or manipulation. They propose mitigations.

all_priority_skills.title: Evaluate an emerging technology from multiple perspectives
all_priority_skills.short_name: Who benefits and who is harmed by a new technology?
all_priority_skills.description: Students evaluate a specific emerging technology (e.g., facial recognition, autonomous vehicles, AI in hiring) through the lens of different stakeholders (developers, users, workers affected by job loss, marginalized communities, environment) and explain how different groups have conflicting interests.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze policy and regulation of an emerging technology
all_priority_skills.description: Students examine how governments and organizations regulate or should regulate emerging technologies (e.g., data privacy laws, AI transparency requirements, content moderation), weighing innovation, safety, freedom, and fairness.

all_priority_skills.title: Investigate personal data collection and privacy
all_priority_skills.short_name: What data do companies collect about you?
all_priority_skills.description: Students investigate what personal data apps and websites collect about them (location, behavior, preferences), how it is used (targeted ads, training AI), and what privacy risks this creates.

all_priority_skills.title: Create a presentation on responsible AI use
all_priority_skills.short_name: Communicate about AI impacts and responsibility
all_priority_skills.description: Students research an AI application (e.g., chatbots, image recognition, recommendation systems) and create a presentation or essay for peers addressing: what it does, who created it, intended benefits, known harms or biases, ethical concerns, and what responsible use looks like.

all_priority_skills.title: Analyze societal impacts of computing technologies
all_priority_skills.short_name: Examine how a technology impacts society and inequality
all_priority_skills.description: Students conduct a research project analyzing how a widely used technology (social media, smartphones, AI assistants, cloud services, surveillance systems, e-commerce) impacts different groups of people, considering access, equity, environmental effects, cultural impacts, and power dynamics. They present nuanced, evidence-based arguments.

all_priority_skills.title: Explore a computing career pathway
all_priority_skills.short_name: Investigate a specific computing career and its requirements
all_priority_skills.description: Students deep-dive into a computing-related career of interest (game developer, data scientist, cybersecurity specialist, AI researcher, software engineer, digital artist, tech policy analyst, etc.), researching education requirements, skills needed, salary range, daily tasks, and how computing interacts with their values and interests. They assess fit with their own aspirations.

all_priority_skills.title: Design a solution with ethics at the center
all_priority_skills.short_name: Create a project that solves a problem fairly
all_priority_skills.description: Students identify a real problem or need (accessibility barrier, environmental challenge, educational gap, social issue) and design a CreatiCode project or prototype that attempts to solve it while explicitly considering: Who is this for? What biases might we introduce? How do we include diverse perspectives in the design? How will we know if it actually helps?

all_priority_skills.title: Communicate professionally about your work
all_priority_skills.short_name: Present your project professionally to diverse audiences
all_priority_skills.description: Students develop a polished presentation or documentation of a substantial project suitable for multiple audiences (classmates, teachers, parents, competition judges, potential employers). They practice adapting their communication to audience, using technical vocabulary appropriately, and conveying both technical details and broader impact.
